original_title: Japan gives US$6.6mn in food grants after monetary instability
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Japan has given 6.6 million US dollars to Sri Lanka through the World Food Programs to support people who could no longer afford to eat after the collapse of an unstable exchange rate arrangement.
Sri Lanka’s rupee fell from 200 to 360 to the US dollar after the central bank printed money for two years to suppress rates through a policy rate and slammed a surrender rule failing a float.
The rupee has since gained after and a surrender rule lifted two weeks ago after phasing out money printing.
Food prices are now falling amid tight monetary policies and rupee appreciation but are still high compared to persons earning fixed wages in rupees.

“We are pleased to announce that the Government of Japan has decided to provide additional humanitarian support to Sri Lanka in this critical moment,” Ambassador of Japan to Sri Lanka Mizukoshi Hideaki said.”
“This support is being used to provide essential food and nutrition to communities across the nation.”
Japan has so far provided 30 million US dollars aid for Sri Lanka through the World Food Program.

WFP’s said the latest surveys indicate that food insecurity is still at a “concerningly high level” and seven in every 10 households cutting back on nutritious food like protein and dairy or skipping meals altogether to cope.
Analysts have suggested monetary reforms in Sri Lanka to curb the ability of the monetary authority to mis-target interest rates and deny monetary stability to the poor. (Colombo/Mar10/2023)
